sn11.10:1.2.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sambahulā isayo sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā samuddatīre paṇṇakuṭīsu sammanti.
sn11.10:1.2.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, several seers who were ethical, of good character, settled in leaf huts on the ocean shore.
sn11.10:1.2.comm: This opening is reminiscent of Ud 1.10, which specifies the location as Suppāraka

sn11.10:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena devāsurasaṅgāmo samupabyūḷho ahosi.
sn11.10:1.3.eng: Now at that time a battle was fought between the gods and the titans.

sn11.10:1.4.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, tesaṃ isīnaṃ sīlavantānaṃ kalyāṇadhammānaṃ etadahosi:

sn11.10:1.5.eng: ‘The gods are principled, the titans are unprincipled.
sn11.10:1.5.comm: The sages may have been virtuous, but they were not above a little realpolitik.

sn11.10:1.6.eng: We may be at risk from the titans.

sn11.10:1.7.pli: Yannūna mayaṃ sambaraṃ asurindaṃ upasaṅkamitvā abhayadakkhiṇaṃ yāceyyāmā’ti.
sn11.10:1.7.eng: Why don’t we approach Sambara, lord of titans, and beg him for a pledge of safety?’
sn11.10:1.7.comm: A barbarian (dāsa) who “fancied himself godlike” (Rig Veda 7.18.20), Śambara’s 99 mountain forts were destroyed for their bounty (6.47.23) by Indra on behalf of Divodāsa Atithigva (4.26.3). His mention close to Virocana (SN 11.8) fits the Arthaśāstra, where they are both invoked together (14.3.19). Despite his decisive defeat at the hands of Indra, later legend makes him a formidable foe and master of sorcery (see SN 11.23).

sn11.10:1.8.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, te isayo sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—samuddatīre paṇṇakuṭīsu antarahitā sambarassa asurindassa sammukhe pāturahesuṃ.
sn11.10:1.8.eng: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, those seers vanished from those leaf huts on the ocean shore and reappeared in Sambara’s presence.

sn11.10:1.9.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, te isayo sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā sambaraṃ asurindaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsiṃsu:
sn11.10:1.9.eng: Then those seers addressed Sambara in verse:

sn11.10:2.2.eng: to beg for a pledge of safety.

sn11.10:2.3.eng: For you can give them what you wish,

sn11.10:3.3.eng: Though you beg me for your safety,

sn11.10:4.1.eng: ‘Though we beg you for our safety,

sn11.10:4.3.eng: This is what we get from you:

sn11.10:4.4.eng: may endless peril come to you!

sn11.10:5.1.eng: Whatever kind of seed you sow,

sn11.10:5.2.eng: that is the fruit you reap.

sn11.10:5.3.eng: A doer of good gets good,

sn11.10:5.4.eng: a doer of bad gets bad.

sn11.10:5.5.eng: You, my dear, have sown your own seed,
sn11.10:5.5.comm: Tāta (“my dear”) here is an endearment of pity (“oh hon”).

sn11.10:6.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, te isayo sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā sambaraṃ asurindaṃ abhisapitvā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—sambarassa asurindassa sammukhe antarahitā samuddatīre paṇṇakuṭīsu pāturahesuṃ.
sn11.10:6.1.eng: Then those seers, having cursed Sambara, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Sambara’s presence and reappeared in those leaf huts on the ocean shore.

sn11.10:6.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sambaro asurindo tehi isīhi sīlavantehi kalyāṇadhammehi abhisapito rattiyā sudaṃ tikkhattuṃ ubbijjī”ti.
sn11.10:6.2.eng: But after being cursed by the seers, Sambara woke in alarm three times that night.”
sn11.10:6.2.comm: This inverts the power of his magic to put people to sleep (Arthaśāstra 14.3.19).

sn11.11:1.2.pli: “Sakkassa, bhikkhave, devānamindassa pubbe manussabhūtassa satta vatapadāni samattāni samādinnāni ahesuṃ, yesaṃ samādinnattā sakko sakkattaṃ ajjhagā.
sn11.11:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, in a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he undertook seven vows. And it was because of undertaking these that he achieved the status of Sakka.
sn11.11:1.2.comm: The oldest stories of Indra already evidence a shift from the violent victory over the serpent Vṛtra (see SN 2.3:3.4) to his liberating the Vala cave, which he did by the power of truth in his role as bṛhaspa﻿ti, the “lord of hymns”. Curiously, just as this discourse follows one featuring Sambara, later legend connects Indra’s power in this life to advice he received from Sambara in the past; namely, to always honor and respect brahmins (Mahābhārata 13.36).

sn11.11:1.3.comm: The seven vows and following verses also appear in the next two discourses.

sn11.11:1.4.eng: As long as I live, may I support my parents.

sn11.11:1.5.eng: As long as I live, may I honor the elders in the family.

sn11.11:1.6.eng: As long as I live, may I speak gently.

sn11.11:1.7.eng: As long as I live, may I not speak divisively.

sn11.11:1.8.pli: yāvajīvaṃ vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvaseyyaṃ muttacāgo payatapāṇi vossaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato,
sn11.11:1.8.eng: As long as I live, may I live at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

sn11.11:1.9.eng: As long as I live, may I speak the truth.

sn11.11:1.10.pli: yāvajīvaṃ akkodhano assaṃ—sacepi me kodho uppajjeyya, khippameva naṃ paṭivineyyanti.
sn11.11:1.10.eng: As long as I live, may I be free of anger, or should anger arise, may I quickly get rid of it.

sn11.11:1.11.pli: Sakkassa, bhikkhave, devānamindassa pubbe manussabhūtassa imāni satta vatapadāni samattāni samādinnāni ahesuṃ, yesaṃ samādinnattā sakko sakkattaṃ ajjhagāti.
sn11.11:1.11.eng: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he undertook seven vows. And it was because of undertaking these that he achieved the status of Sakka.

sn11.11:2.1.eng: A child who respects their parents,
sn11.11:2.1.comm: Here jantu shows its original meaning of “one who is born”, namely a human child.

sn11.11:2.2.eng: and honors the elders in the family,

sn11.11:2.3.eng: whose speech is gentle and courteous,

sn11.11:3.1.eng: who’s committed to getting rid of stinginess,

sn11.11:3.2.eng: is truthful, and has mastered anger:

sn11.11:3.3.eng: the gods of the thirty-three declare

sn11.11:3.4.eng: them to be a true person.”

sn11.12:1.2.eng: There the Buddha said to the mendicants:

sn11.12:1.3.pli: “sakko, bhikkhave, devānamindo pubbe manussabhūto samāno magho nāma māṇavo ahosi, tasmā maghavāti vuccati.
sn11.12:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, in a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he was a student named Magha. That’s why he’s called Maghavā, the Bounteous One.
sn11.12:1.3.comm: Maghavā (“bounteous one”) is a common epithet of Indra (eg. Rig Veda 3.39.09a, Atharva Veda 8.4.19a, Kauṣītaki Brāhmaṇa 24.5.22). It is from the Vedic magha, “gift, bounty”. The name Māgha, with the same meaning, is a name of Sakka at SN 2.3, while at Snp 3.5:1.3 a brahmin student Māgha asks about generosity. Finally, the good king of MN 83 is named Maghadeva, “god of bounty”. The passage here attributes the name to his ancestry, but it goes on to praise his generosity.

sn11.12:2.1.pli: Sakko, bhikkhave, devānamindo pubbe manussabhūto samāno pure dānaṃ adāsi, tasmā purindadoti vuccati.
sn11.12:2.1.eng: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he was first to give gifts. That’s why he’s called Purindada, the Firstgiver.
sn11.12:2.1.comm: Purandara (“Fortbreaker”) is another epithet (eg. Rig Veda 1.102.7). The Buddha reforms it to Purindada (“Firstgiver”) at SN 11.12:2.1. But Indra’s generosity is long renowned: “He is the able one, and he will be able for us—Indra who distributes the goods” (Rig Veda 1.10.6).

sn11.12:3.1.pli: Sakko, bhikkhave, devānamindo pubbe manussabhūto samāno sakkaccaṃ dānaṃ adāsi, tasmā sakkoti vuccati.
sn11.12:3.1.eng: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he gave gifts ably. That’s why he’s called Sakka, the Able.
sn11.12:3.1.comm: Sakka (śakra, the “able one”) was originally an epithet of Indra. |

sn11.12:4.1.pli: Sakko, bhikkhave, devānamindo pubbe manussabhūto samāno āvasathaṃ adāsi, tasmā vāsavoti vuccati.
sn11.12:4.1.eng: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he gave the gift of a guest house. That’s why he’s called Vāsava, the Houser.
sn11.12:4.1.comm: Vāsava means “endowed with wealth” (vasu; see for example Rig Veda 1.9.9a indraṁ vasupatiṁ “Indra, lord of wealth”). This passage, rather, plays on the word āvasatha and calls him the “giver of a guesthouse”. Later Brahmanical texts enumerated eight Vasus, with Indra as their lord, who are reckoned among the thirty-three.

sn11.12:5.1.pli: Sakko, bhikkhave, devānamindo sahassampi atthānaṃ muhuttena cinteti, tasmā sahassakkhoti vuccati.
sn11.12:5.1.eng: Sakka thinks of a thousand needs in an hour. That’s why he’s called Sahassakkha, the Thousand-Eyed.
sn11.12:5.1.comm: “Thousand eyes” is sahassakkha, more commonly sahassanetta SN 11.9:2.3, Snp 2.12:5.4, Thag 21.1:58.4). In the Rig Veda it describes the sparkle of the Soma, perhaps alluding to its visionary effects (9.60, 9.65.7). It is in this context that Indra, along with Vāyu, is first called “thousand-eyed” (1.23.3). It is also used for Agni, the fire with eyes all around (1.79.12, 10.79.5). | “Needs” (atthā) here recalls SN 11.8:5.1.

sn11.12:6.1.pli: Sakkassa, bhikkhave, devānamindassa sujā nāma asurakaññā pajāpati, tasmā sujampatīti vuccati.
sn11.12:6.1.eng: Sakka’s wife is the titan maiden named Sujā. That’s why he’s called Sujampati, Sujā’s Husband.
sn11.12:6.1.comm: Sanskrit sources know his wife as Śacī (“the powerful”), daughter of the titan maiden Pulomā, who came to be known as Indrāṇī. The Pali sujampati (“Sujā’s husband”) evidently draws from Indra’s epithet śacīpati (“lord of power”; Rig Veda 1.106.06, 4.30.17, 8.15.13). But as Śacī Paulomī she is also author of a Vedic hymn in her own right (10.159). There she gains power through the same oblation by which Indra gained his power in order to gain victory over her co-wives and husband (“only my will should my husband follow”; “I will rule widely over this hero and over his people”). Indra was evidently not threatened by a powerful woman and took her to wife. Sujā should be considered the Pali spelling of śacī. These indomitable characters forged a harmonious relationship, as seen when they share domestic duties by working together at the loom (Ud 3.7:3.2).

sn11.12:7.1.pli: Sakko, bhikkhave, devānamindo devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kāreti, tasmā devānamindoti vuccati.
sn11.12:7.1.eng: Sakka rules as sovereign lord over the gods of the thirty-three. That’s why he’s called Devānaminda, the Lord of Gods.
sn11.12:7.1.comm: The concept of 33 gods goes back as far as Rig Veda 8.28.1. The number is a reduplication of the trinity. In Buddhist texts they are not enumerated, but Yājñavalkya reckons them as eight Vasus, eleven Rudras, twelve Ādityas, plus Indra and Prajāpati (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.9.2). The final pair are elsewhere said to be Dyaus (“Heaven” = Zeus) and Pṛthivī (“Earth”), or the twin Aśvins.

sn11.12:8.1.pli: Sakkassa, bhikkhave, devānamindassa pubbe manussabhūtassa satta vatapadāni samattāni samādinnāni ahesuṃ, yesaṃ samādinnattā sakko sakkattaṃ ajjhagā.
sn11.12:8.1.eng: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he undertook seven vows. And it was because of undertaking these that he achieved the status of Sakka.

sn11.12:8.3.eng: As long as I live, may I support my parents.

sn11.12:8.4.eng: As long as I live, may I honor the elders in the family.

sn11.12:8.5.eng: As long as I live, may I speak gently.

sn11.12:8.6.eng: As long as I live, may I not speak divisively.

sn11.12:8.7.eng: As long as I live, may I live at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

sn11.12:8.8.eng: As long as I live, may I speak the truth.

sn11.12:8.9.eng: As long as I live, may I be free of anger, or should anger arise, may I quickly get rid of it.

sn11.12:8.10.eng: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he undertook seven vows. And it was because of undertaking these that he achieved the status of Sakka.

sn11.12:9.1.eng: A child who respects their parents,

sn11.12:9.2.eng: and honors the elders in the family,

sn11.12:9.3.eng: whose speech is gentle and courteous,

sn11.12:10.1.eng: who’s committed to getting rid of stinginess,

sn11.12:10.2.eng: is truthful, and has mastered anger:

sn11.12:10.3.eng: the gods of the thirty-three declare

sn11.12:10.4.eng: them to be a true person.”

sn11.13:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
sn11.13:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

sn11.13:1.3.pli: Atha kho mahāli licchavī yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho mahāli licchavī bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn11.13:1.3.eng: Then Mahāli the Licchavi went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
sn11.13:1.3.comm: Mahāli also features in AN 10.47 on the causes of good and bad deeds; in SN 22.60 on Pūraṇa Kassapa’s theory that there is no purification of beings; and in DN 6, where he is called Oṭṭhaddha (“hare-lip”) and shows himself to be familiar with the failed ascetic Sunakkhatta.

sn11.13:2.1.eng: “Sir, have you seen Sakka, lord of gods?”

sn11.13:4.1.eng: “But surely, sir, you must have seen someone who looked like Sakka.

sn11.13:4.2.eng: For Sakka is hard to see.”
sn11.13:4.2.comm: In DN 6 he also asks about seeing celestial visions, and the Buddha gives a detailed explanation in terms of meditation attainments.

sn11.13:5.1.pli: “Sakkañca khvāhaṃ, mahāli, pajānāmi sakkakaraṇe ca dhamme, yesaṃ dhammānaṃ samādinnattā sakko sakkattaṃ ajjhagā, tañca pajānāmi.
sn11.13:5.1.eng: “Mahāli, I understand Sakka. And I understand the things that he undertook and committed to, which enabled him to achieve the status of Sakka.

sn11.13:6.1.pli: Sakko, mahāli, devānamindo pubbe manussabhūto samāno magho nāma māṇavo ahosi, tasmā maghavāti vuccati.
sn11.13:6.1.eng: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he was a student named Magha. That’s why he’s called Maghavā, the Bounteous.

sn11.13:7.1.eng: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he gave gifts ably. That’s why he’s called Sakka, the Able.

sn11.13:8.1.eng: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he was first to give gifts. That’s why he’s called Purindada, the Firstgiver.

sn11.13:9.1.eng: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he gave the gift of a guest house. That’s why he’s called Vāsava, the Houser.

sn11.13:10.1.eng: Sakka thinks of a thousand things in an hour. That’s why he’s called Sahassakkha, the Thousand-Eyed.

sn11.13:11.1.eng: Sakka’s wife is the titan maiden named Sujā. That’s why he’s called Sujampati, Sujā’s Husband.

sn11.13:12.1.pli: Sakko, mahāli, devānamindo devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kāreti, tasmā devānamindoti vuccati.
sn11.13:12.1.eng: Sakka rules as sovereign lord over the gods of the thirty-three. That’s why he’s called Devānaminda, the Lord of Gods.

sn11.13:13.1.eng: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he undertook seven vows. And it was because of undertaking these that he achieved the status of Sakka.

sn11.13:13.3.eng: As long as I live, may I support my parents.

sn11.13:13.4.eng: As long as I live, may I honor the elders in the family.

sn11.13:13.5.eng: As long as I live, may I speak gently.

sn11.13:13.6.eng: As long as I live, may I not speak divisively.

sn11.13:13.7.eng: As long as I live, may I live at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

sn11.13:13.8.eng: As long as I live, may I speak the truth.

sn11.13:13.9.eng: As long as I live, may I be free of anger, or should anger arise, may I quickly get rid of it.

sn11.13:13.10.pli: Sakkassa, mahāli, devānamindassa pubbe manussabhūtassa imāni satta vatapadāni samattāni samādinnāni ahesuṃ, yesaṃ samādinnattā sakko sakkattaṃ ajjhagāti.
sn11.13:13.10.eng: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he undertook seven vows. And it was because of undertaking these that he achieved the status of Sakka.

sn11.13:14.1.eng: A child who respects their parents,

sn11.13:14.2.eng: and honors the elders in the family,

sn11.13:14.3.eng: whose speech is gentle and courteous,

sn11.13:15.1.eng: who’s committed to getting rid of stinginess,

sn11.13:15.2.eng: is truthful, and has mastered anger:

sn11.13:15.3.eng: the gods of the thirty-three declare

sn11.13:15.4.eng: them to be a true person.”

sn11.14:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn11.14:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn11.14:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn11.14:2.1.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, aññataro puriso imasmiṃyeva rājagahe manussadaliddo ahosi manussakapaṇo manussavarāko.
sn11.14:2.1.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a poor person, destitute and pitiful.

sn11.14:2.2.pli: So tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye saddhaṃ samādiyi, sīlaṃ samādiyi, sutaṃ samādiyi, cāgaṃ samādiyi, paññaṃ samādiyi.
sn11.14:2.2.eng: They took up faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One.

sn11.14:2.3.pli: So tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye saddhaṃ samādiyitvā sīlaṃ samādiyitvā sutaṃ samādiyitvā cāgaṃ samādiyitvā paññaṃ samādiyitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajji devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyataṃ.
sn11.14:2.3.eng: After undertaking these things, when their body broke up, after death, they were reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, in the company of the gods of the thirty-three.

sn11.14:2.4.pli: So aññe deve atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
sn11.14:2.4.eng: There they outshone the other gods in beauty and glory.

sn11.14:2.5.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti:
sn11.14:2.5.eng: But the gods of the thirty-three complained, grumbled, and objected,

sn11.14:2.7.pli: Ayañhi devaputto pubbe manussabhūto samāno manussadaliddo ahosi manussakapaṇo manussavarāko;
sn11.14:2.7.eng: For when this godling was a human being in their past life they were poor, destitute, and pitiful.

sn11.14:2.8.pli: so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapanno devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyataṃ.
sn11.14:2.8.eng: And when their body broke up, after death, they were reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, in the company of the gods of the thirty-three.

sn11.14:2.9.pli: So aññe deve atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā cā’ti.
sn11.14:2.9.eng: Here they outshine the other gods in beauty and glory.’

sn11.14:3.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo deve tāvatiṃse āmantesi:
sn11.14:3.1.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the gods of the thirty-three,

sn11.14:3.2.pli: ‘mā kho tumhe, mārisā, etassa devaputtassa ujjhāyittha.
sn11.14:3.2.eng: ‘Good fellows, don’t complain about this god.

sn11.14:3.3.pli: Eso kho, mārisā, devaputto pubbe manussabhūto samāno tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye saddhaṃ samādiyi, sīlaṃ samādiyi, sutaṃ samādiyi, cāgaṃ samādiyi, paññaṃ samādiyi.
sn11.14:3.3.eng: When this godling was a human being in their past life they took up faith, ethics, learning, generosity, and wisdom in the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One.

sn11.14:3.4.pli: So tathāgatappavedite dhammavinaye saddhaṃ samādiyitvā sīlaṃ samādiyitvā sutaṃ samādiyitvā cāgaṃ samādiyitvā paññaṃ samādiyitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapanno devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sahabyataṃ.
sn11.14:3.4.eng: After undertaking these things, when their body broke up, after death, they’ve been reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, in the company of the gods of the thirty-three.

sn11.14:3.5.pli: So aññe deve atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā cā’ti.
sn11.14:3.5.eng: Here they outshine the other gods in beauty and glory.’

sn11.14:3.6.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo deve tāvatiṃse anunayamāno tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn11.14:3.6.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, guiding the gods of the thirty-three, spoke this verse:

sn11.14:4.1.eng: ‘Whoever has faith in the Realized One,

sn11.14:4.4.eng: praised and loved by the noble ones;

sn11.14:5.1.eng: who has confidence in the Saṅgha,

sn11.14:5.4.eng: their life is not in vain.

sn11.14:6.1.eng: So let the wise devote themselves

sn11.14:6.3.eng: confidence, and insight into the teaching,

sn11.14:6.4.eng: remembering the instructions of the Buddhas.’”

sn11.15:1.2.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn11.15:1.2.eng: And then Sakka, lord of gods, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,

sn11.15:2.3.eng: are not worth a sixteenth part

sn11.15:3.2.eng: in a valley or the uplands,

sn11.16:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
sn11.16:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

sn11.16:1.2.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
sn11.16:1.2.eng: And then Sakka, lord of gods, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,

sn11.16:1.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:

sn11.16:2.4.eng: where is a gift very fruitful?”

sn11.16:3.2.eng: and four established in the fruit.

sn11.16:4.4.eng: what is given to the Saṅgha is very fruitful.”

sn11.17:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā divāvihāragato hoti paṭisallīno.
sn11.17:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Buddha had gone into retreat for the day’s meditation.

sn11.17:1.3.pli: Atha kho sakko ca devānamindo brahmā ca sahampati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā paccekaṃ dvārabāhaṃ nissāya aṭṭhaṃsu.
sn11.17:1.3.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, and the divinity Sahampati approached the Buddha and stationed themselves one by each door-post.
sn11.17:1.3.comm: The form of this discourse echoes that of SN 11.8, with Sakka and Sahampati in the roles of Verocana and Sakka. This time it is Sakka who gives the inferior verse that is trumped by Sahampati.

sn11.17:1.4.pli: Atha kho sakko devānamindo bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn11.17:1.4.eng: Then Sakka spoke this verse in the Buddha’s presence:

sn11.17:2.1.eng: “Rise, hero! Victor in battle, with burden put down,

sn11.17:2.2.eng: wander the world free of debt.

sn11.17:2.4.eng: like the moon on the fifteenth night.”
sn11.17:2.4.comm: Sakka speaks to the personal liberation of the Buddha.

sn11.17:3.1.eng: “Lord of gods, that’s not how to pay homage to the Realized Ones.

sn11.17:3.2.eng: This is how it should be done:

sn11.17:4.1.eng: ‘Rise, hero! Victor in battle, caravan leader,

sn11.17:4.2.eng: wander the world free of debt.

sn11.17:4.3.eng: Let the Blessed One teach the Dhamma!

sn11.17:4.4.eng: There will be those who understand!’”
sn11.17:4.4.comm: Sahampati encourages the Buddha to teach for the liberation of all beings, as he did after the Buddha’s awakening (SN 6.1:8.1).
